In a time of social distancing, we're celebrating student achievements through live video.

Wojciech P, a student at the NE Metro 916 Career and Technical Center, was the only student to earn the prestigious $1,000 Kopp Leadership Scholarship from Century College. After spending a year in the Animal Science program, Wojciech joined the Careers in Education program and realized he wanted to combine his passions to eventually become a high school biology teacher.

In his time at Career and Tech, he has been a Student Ambassador in both programs he attended; been a class leader and role model for students; facilitated tours for prospective students, teachers, administrators, and legislators; and helped raise money for other 916 sites at the 916 Education Foundation Annual Gala.

Outside of the Career and Tech Center, he has demonstrated a strong commitment to leadership and community service by installing bird and bat houses in the City of Mahtomedi. He has also been known to stand in the rain or snow to hold doors open for others, so they can seek shelter quickly. Congrats, Wojciech!

April 1 at 1:58 PM ¬∑

Northeast Metro 916 Intermediate School District kicked off learning at Cambia Hills today with their first student, but done through distance learning due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Students will be grouped by age, receiving instruction in the elementary, middle school or high school classroom. Elementary and Middle School students will access academic content at their grade level. Given the distance learning model, teachers will use academic progress information from the students most recent educational provider to tailor the curriculum to their individual needs. High School students will receive their instruction using online curriculum that targets the specific courses they need to graduate. Northeast Metro 916 staff will collaborate with Cambia Hills of East Bethel staff to deliver instruction during distance learning during the pandemic. Northeast Metro 916 and Cambia Hills staff say they are excited to work together as we begin this wonderful new partnership! (pictured is Tammy Bednar, our Principal)

There was a situation that occurred at Karner Blue today. First, please be reassured that all students and staff are safe.

Today, a staff person reported a smell in one of our learning communities that she thought could have been a gas leak. We followed our emergency procedures, and immediately moved all staff and students away from the area while the fire department investigated the situation. We opted not to evacuate based on our consultation with the fire department.

The fire department determined that no gas leak was present and there was no cause for concern. Students and staff returned to their regular schedules and classrooms.

Creating a safe environment for our students and staff is a top priority. We are proud of how our students and staff responded to this incident and followed our safety procedures.

Dan Porter and Cara McGlynn, two social workers at 916, shared their expertise with school districts statewide at the School Mental Health Conference.

Their presentation, titled "Implementing a Trauma Informed School Wide Support System in Your School," was a popular topic that was well-received by participants. "The energy was amazing," said Kristin Logfren, school mental health project lead for the Minnesota Department of Human Services. "Their presentation was impressive and I thank them for sharing their expertise."

"I am proud that the world is finding out the commitment of the staff of 916 to our mission," said Superintendent Hayes. "Dan and Cara showcased how every one of our staff is responding to the unique needs of students with innovation, quality and experience."

Staff at Karner Blue Education Center start their Tuesdays and Thursdays together for round of what they call "mental release and stretch," a wellness activity that includes mindfulness, gentle yoga and stretching.

Ryan Buycks came up with the idea as a way for people who work in separate areas of the school to build community, relieve stress, and ultimately support each other in a healthy way. "People used to just sit in their cars in the morning before school starts," Ryan said. "This way we can all come together and find some peace before a hectic day."

"The same kind of community building that happens in a happy hour also happens in our mental release and stretch," said Annika Larson, one of the coordinators of the group. She credits Ryan's role on the CARE team with giving him a unique perspective on what students and staff at Karner Blue need to be successful.

The Minnesota Landscape Arboretum partnered with a private donor to grant Karner Blue Education Center a kaleidoscope garden last month to benefit their nature-based instructional model. Kaleidoscope gardens are large steel structures with a miniature garden at their center. They invite the viewer to change their gaze in order to experience multiple perspectives, color combinations and textures.

The Habits of Resilience blog suggests taking a kaleidoscope approach to viewing others who we find difficult, abrasive or offensive. "If we shift our view of what seems ordinary and objectionable, we may find something in the other we can appreciate, possibly even admire," the blog states.
